nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates of economic damages from climate change and IAMs calibrated to them (notably DICE) severely underestimate damages and are unsuitable for evaluating climate risk or guiding policy
Prominent economic damage estimates are quantitatively trivial (e.g., DICE damage function predicts about 2.1% loss at 3C and 7.9% at 6C)
Economists' empirical methods systematically neglect climatic tipping points and misrepresent the scientific literature on tipping risks

Common economic methodologies used to estimate damages are flawed: enumeration (sector omission), cross-sectional spatial proxies, CGE adaptation assumptions, small expert surveys, and shared biased data sets
The DICE model architecture (a Ramsey-based IAM) structurally prevents modeled economic collapse and assumes full employment, exogenous productivity and saddle-path stability
Because IAMs like DICE, FUND, PAGE are calibrated to the flawed empirical estimates and are used to compute the Social Cost of Carbon, policy has been guided by these underestimates
Evidence: IPCC-AR5 and Nordhaus-based damage calibrations show small global impacts across a range of studies and Nordhaus progressively reduced his damage function convexity over revisions

Evidence: Post-2014 empirical studies that attempt improvements still use time-trend extrapolations or spatial proxies and often retain the assumption that mainly weather-exposed sectors determine damages
Evidence: Climate science literature (Lenton et al., expert elicitations) identifies multiple tipping elements likely triggerable this century and tipping cascades that amplify impacts
Evidence: Nordhaus and others mis-cited Lenton et al. to justify excluding tipping points and assigned very low probabilities to catastrophic events (e.g., AMOC), artificially downweighting damages

Evidence: Enumeration and statistical methods commonly assume industries not directly exposed to weather (manufacturing, services, government) are insulated from climate change, omitting interdependencies and input dependencies

Result: Sensitivity analysis of DICE shows that even with much larger damage coefficients the model produces corner solutions (full mitigation, extreme carbon prices) and eventual economic recovery rather than collapse; only at extreme parameterization the solver fails

Explanation/Evidence: DICE uses Cobb-Douglas production with exogenous labor and TFP, full employment, and saddle-path boundary conditions, which mathematically preclude endogenous systemic collapse under damages

Evidence: Expert elicitation and surveys show large divergence: climate scientists foresee far larger damages than many economists, yet economic surveys and small expert panels were used to justify low damage estimates

Conclusion: Given methodological errors (sector omissions, flawed spatial/time proxies, underweighted tipping risks), structural model constraints (DICE/Ramsey), and calibration to biased data, economists' damage estimates and IAM outputs should be rejected for assessing climate risks and informing policy
